The Vision

Thereâ€™s a scene I love in Iron-Man 2: Tony Stark standing in front of floating holograms, manipulating them with a casual swipe of his hand.
Itâ€™s cinematic, but itâ€™s also the perfect metaphor for human-computer interaction: intuitive, responsive, alive.

I wanted to recreate that feeling on a regular desktop. No special hardware, just a monitor and a webcam.
And thatâ€™s how SHolo (Screen Hologram) was born.

SHolo transforms your screen into a 3D holographic illusion: it tracks your eyes to create real-time parallax and lets you move objects through natural hand gestures.
Look around, swipe, or hold your hand still: the object responds like itâ€™s truly suspended in front of you!

The Concept

Before writing a single line of code, I started by answering something simple: how do we perceive depth?

And so I played around with real-world objects: moving them, keeping my eyes still, rolling my eyes, â€¦ and I found something very simple but powerful (I could have just Googled it, but it wouldn't have been as fun):

Manuel(*)'s Theorem

- When you move only your eyes, the world stays still.

- When you move your head, everything shifts: that's what gives us the true sense of three-dimensionality.

(*) I am Manuel

Thatâ€™s when I realized: itâ€™s not how the eyes move that matters, but where they are.

So, like any engineer trying to simplify a complex system, I reduced the problem to its essence: tracking only the pupilsâ€™ position through a webcam.

By capturing the eyesâ€™ relative position and estimating their distance from the camera through interpupillary distance mapped to pixel distance and the cameraâ€™s field of view, I could reconstruct a virtual version of my viewpoint inside the software!

From there, it was just a matter of connecting that virtual â€œcameraâ€ to the 3D rendering engine.

That was all! No special hardware.
Just a webcam, a monitor, and a bit of math. So i started codingâ€¦

Now Technical

At its core, SHolo is an experimental Python application that brings together MediaPipe, OpenCV, Trimesh, and PyVista/Pyglet into a multi-threaded 3D environment.

Core pipeline

  1. Face & eye tracking â†’ MediaPipe Face Mesh locates eyes, estimates inter-pupillary distance (IPD), and maps gaze offset to yaw/pitch camera rotation.

  2. Hand tracking â†’ MediaPipe Hands detects swipes and open-palm gestures to control motion.

  3. 3D rendering â†’ The scene is rendered in Trimesh via PyVista/Pyglet, with live transformations driven by the detected inputs.

  4. Thread orchestration â†’ The OpenCV detection loop runs independently from the Pyglet viewer to maintain responsiveness and avoid frame drops.

The result: a seamless interaction where your eyes control view, and your hands control motion.
